I know there is a lot of software out there that largely replaces props and such visual effects, but on a low budget, or just the right look, it's nice to know. I don't know if movies used to do the same thing, but I can see that being a way to replicate many scenes easily.

I think its not because of the sand being hot, but the hot surface under the sand, where the water reacts to the hotness of the pan that produces steam that makes the fine sand look like it is boiling. Salt on the other hand tries to absorb the water before it goes on the lower surface which I believe the reason why it did not make the salt to not boil like the sand when water got dripped in.

You are getting the response you are because it is not sand! it is a true glass product and though made from sand it is not the same thing, I would hazard an educated guess that the spreading of the water drops is because of the "sand" being glass and no matter the size when you drop water (or any fluid) on to glass it will shatter thus causing the liquid to spray out in different directions  Using playground sand would have allowed the water to be " slightly" absorbed before boiling. By slightly absorbed I am talking milliseconds which would have stopped the popping away from the drop
